questions.text: What is the approximate time interval between HIV infection & manifestation of AIDS?
questions.solution:
The time interval between primary HIV infection and the manifestation of AIDS is 10 years.

After exposure to the HIV virus, there occurs primary infection following an incubation period of 2-4 weeks, which is usually symptomatic in more than 50% of cases, following 3-6 weeks there is acute HIV syndrome due to wide dissemination of the virus, characterized by fever, sore throat, diarrhea, lymphadenopathy, and rash.

This peak viremia drops as the immune response develops, to reach a plateau about 3 months later. Following this there is a prolonged period of clinical latency, during which infected individuals are asymptomatic, lasting for a median of 10 years.

Following this period, chronic persistent infection develops which is the hallmark of HIV disease called Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).

Long-term non-progressors: a small part of untreated HIV-infected people with CD4 counts within the reference range for >10 years. 

Elite controllers: Some long-term non-progressors have undetectable viral loads.

questions.text: Which of the following case scenarios depict a mode of transmission that carries the highest risk of acquiring HIV?

choices.text: A 23-year-old drug addict sharing syringes during intravenous drug abuse
A 15-year-old thalassemic adolescent undergoing blood transfusion
A 30-year-old man engaging in unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners
A 27-year-old nurse accidentally injuring herself while drawing blood

questions.solution:
Blood transfusion carries the highest risk of acquiring HIV.

Salient features of transmission of HIV:

  • The highest risk of acquiring HIV from an infected source is via blood transfusion > needle sharing during drug abuse > receptive anal intercourse > needle-stick injury > vaginal & oral sexual intercourse.
  • The most common mode of transmission worldwide is sexual transmission (heterosexual in India) > mother to child > least common modes are blood transfusion & needle-stick injury.
  • Male to female transmission > female to male transmission.
  • Viral load is highest in blood > semen > vaginal fluid > breastmilk & saliva and minimal to absent in tears, sweat & urine.

questions.text: Which statement regarding HIV infection is true?

choices.text: HIV-2 is more pathogenic than HIV -1
HIV-1 subtype C is the most common form worldwide
Donated blood is not screened for HIV- 2

questions.solution:
HIV-1 subtype C is the most common form worldwide.

Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) has two serotypes HIV-1 and HIV- 2 based on differences in the env (envelope) gene. 

HIV-1 is further divided into 4 distinct groups, group M (major)/N/O/P. The M group comprises nine subtypes A, B, C, D, F, G, H, J, and K.

  • Subtype C is the most common form worldwide & is more associated with heterosexual transmission.
  • Subtype B is more associated with spread through blood and homosexual contact.

Options A, C: HIV- 2 is less pathogenic than HIV-1 and is predominantly confined to Africa.

Option D: Donated blood is screened for both HIV -1 & HIV-2.

questions.text: A 47-year-old phlebotomist suffered a needle-stick injury while drawing blood from a patient with HIV. Which of the following mutations in him can cause a resistance to acquiring HIV infection?
questions.solution:
CCR 5 delta 32 mutation causes resistance to HIV infection. It is a mutated allele that causes a lack of surface expression of the CCR5 co-receptor resulting in blockade of HIV entry and resistance to HIV infection.

Homozygous alleles cause complete resistance to HIV infection & heterozygous alleles cause partial resistance.

CXCR4 and CCR5 are chemokine receptors (co-receptors) present on the surface of CD4+ T-helper cells & macrophages that aid in the fusion and entry of the HIV virus. 

DC-SIGN is a type of cell surface lectin receptor to which the HIV virus has the affinity to bind. The expression of this type of receptor on dendritic cells (antigen-presenting cells) enhances the infectivity of HIV.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the casualty with a 24-hour history of fever, sore throat, and diffuse erythematous macular rash. Past history is positive for unprotected intercourse with a new partner. What is true about the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute HIV syndrome. The virus is transmissible during this early infection period.

It is characterized by acute burst of viremia and wide virus dissemination and seeding of lymphoid organs (e.g., gut-associated lymphoid tissue), culminating in the destruction of CD4+ cells. 

The p24 antigen capture assay is used as a screening test for HIV infection in patients suspected of having the acute HIV syndrome.

Option A: The incubation period for acute HIV syndrome is around 3 to 6 weeks.

Option B: The acute HIV syndrome is typical of an acute viral syndrome and is very similar to acute infectious mononucleosis. The clinical findings include fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy. Rash, headache, arthralgia, and anorexia/weight loss can also be seen.

Option D: Opportunistic infections can occur during this stage of infection, reflecting the immunodeficiency that results from reduced numbers of CD4+T cells.

questions.text: What is the correct WHO staging for an HIV-infected child with unexplained persistent parotid enlargement?
questions.solution:
Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement in an HIV-infected child is categorized as stage 2 of HIV disease according to WHO staging.

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

General-

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Oral-

  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema

Skin- 

  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Herpes zoster

Stage 3

General-

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Oral-

  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis

Respiratory-

  • Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Stage 4

General-

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Chronic herpes simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

Neurological-

  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)

Respiratory-

  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)

questions.text: An HIV-positive individual presents with the following finding. What is the diagnosis & WHO staging?
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis (thrush) is categorized as WHO stage 3.

Oral candidiasis and oral hairy leukoplakia are oral lesions categorized as WHO clinical stage 3. They generally occur in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <300/μL.

  Oral candidiasis Oral hairy leukoplakia

Cause

Candida albicans

 Epstein-Barr virus 
Appearance

White, plaque-like lesions with cheesy exudate, on an erythematous mucosa

White, frond-like lesions with hair-like growths from folds in the patches
Location  Posterior oropharynx Lateral borders of tongue
Clinical features

Typically painful, can be easily brushed off

 Typically painless, cannot be brushed 
Investigation 

KOH preparation demonstrates budding yeasts, hyphae, or pseudohyphae

Despite its name, it is not considered premalignant. 
Treatment   Antifungals Antivirals

questions.text: What is the most common opportunistic infection in HIV-infected individuals?
questions.solution:
Tuberculosisis the most common opportunistic infection in HIV-infected individuals globally and in India.

In patients with relatively high CD4+ T cell counts, the typical pattern of pulmonary reactivation occurs (60–80%). In patients with lower CD4+ T cell counts, disseminated disease is seen.

Primary prophylaxis: Isoniazid and pyridoxine for 9 months for HIV-infected individuals meeting the following conditions:

  • PPD skin-test reaction of >5 mm or,
  • Positive IFN-γ release assay or,
  • Close household contacts of persons with active tuberculosis

questions.text: A previously untreated HIV-positive patient is diagnosed with tuberculosis and treatment is initiated for both the diseases. Two weeks into treatment, he suddenly complains of high fever, severe malaise and worsening cough. What is the likely explanation?

choices.text: Bacterial endotoxin release due to death of TB bacilli

questions.solution:
Concurrent treatment with anti-retroviral therapy is the most likely explanation in this case resulting in Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS). Its characteristics are:

  • Temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms (lymphadenopathy, fever or worsening of pulmonary infiltrations, pleural effusion) and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ART. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT. 
  • It is seen weeks to months following the initiation of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART).
  • It is most common in previously untreated patients starting therapy with a CD4+ T cell count <50/μL who experience a sudden drop in viral load.
  • The earlier ART is started and the lower the baseline CD4+ T-cell count, the greater the risk of IRIS.
  • In severe cases, the use of immunosuppressive drugs such as glucocorticoids may be required to blunt the inflammatory component of IRIS while specific antimicrobial therapy takes effect.

Note: Hypersensitivity to isoniazid is extremely rare and the presentation includes maculopapular rash.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals the following finding. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. What is the most common cause of this condition in such patients?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with a positive Kernig's sign, is suggestive of meningitis. Cryptococcus is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS. It generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.            

Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated (yeast colonies obstruct the free flow of CSF causing increased CSF pressure).

The diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with india ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination (CrAg).

Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Treatment:

  • Induction - IV or liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance -  Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.

Melanoma is not an AIDS-defining malignancy.

AIDS-defining malignancies are those cancers that a human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infected person is at a high risk of developing. When a HIV-infected person develops one of the AIDS-defining malignancies it suggests that he has AIDS.

AIDS-defining malignancies include the following:

  • Kaposi sarcoma - It is a multicentric neoplasm of vascular origin and has a strong association with HHV - 8.
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Invasive cervical cancer

Given below is the image of kaposi sarcoma:

Note : The FDA has approved pomalidomide, a thalidomide analogue to be included in treating adult patients with AIDS-related Kaposi's sarcoma after failure of highly active antiretroviral therapy and Kaposi's sarcoma in adult patients who are HIV-negative.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive woman presented with fever and malaise. She gives a history of bleeding from the following lesions. Warthin-Starry staining of a biopsy sample taken from the lesion showed which organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacillary angiomatosis in an immunocompromised patient. Warthin-Starry stain would show Bartonella henselae as the causative organism in these skin lesions.

Bacillary angiomatosis is an infectious vascular proliferative lesion presenting as reddish-purple nodules similar to KS lesions (caused by HHV-8). The diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The drug of choice for treatment is erythromycin.

The image given below shows the Warthin-Starry stained lesion showing tangled pleomorphic bacilli.

Option B: HHV 8 is strongly associated with Kaposi sarcoma.

Option C: Bartonella bacilliformis causes Oroya fever.

Option D: EBV causes infectious mononucleosis.

Note: Bartonella henselae causes cat-scratch disease, a necrotizing granulomatous disorder of lymph nodes, in immunocompetent hosts.

questions.text: An HIV-positive woman was rushed to the ICU following an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. There was no history of fever, night sweats or weight loss. MRI scan is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis. MRI scan shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

It usually has multiple lesions in multiple locations which are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Sometimes an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring; this so-called eccentric target sign is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Surrounding edema is also present.

Treatment includes sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 

Primary prophylaxis: It is given to patients with IgG antibody to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL. A single double strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given.

Secondary prophyaxis/maintanace therapy: It is given when CD4+ T cell counts <200 cells/μL. Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin is given. It is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are maintained >200/μL for 6 months.

Option A: Cryptococcal meningitis presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. Seizures and focal neurologic deficits are rarely seen. MRI findings include dilated perivascular spaces and basal ganglia pseudocysts. 

Option B: Primary CNS lymphoma also presents with seizures and focal neurological deficit. Symptoms of fever, night sweats and weight loss are present in 80% of the patients. On imaging, it is identified as a CT hyperdense enhancing supratentorial mass, with MRI T1 hypointense, T2 iso- to hypointense, vivid homogeneous enhancement as well as restricted diffusion. 

Option C: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, caused by JC virus, is characterized by demyelination in subcortical white matter reflected on MRI as multiple, non-enhancing white matter lesions.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except:
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis, although seen in AIDS patients, is not an AIDS-defining illness. Candidiasis of the esophagus, trachea, bronchi, and lungs are AIDS-defining illnesses. 

AIDS-defining illnesses are specific opportunistic illnesses in patients with AIDS, which signify an advanced stage of illness (Stage 3).

A case of HIV can be classified into five stages as per current CDC guidelines (0, 1, 2, 3, and unknown).

Stage

 Criteria CD4+ count (>5 years)

0

 A negative HIV test within 6 months of first diagnosis NA
1 Based on CD4+ count >=500
2 Based on CD4+ count 200-499
3 AIDS-defining opportunistic illness <200
unknown Unavailable CD4+ counts unknown

questions.text: An HIV-positive woman was referred to the ophthalmology OPD for decreased visual acuity. She described her vision as blurry with apparent flies floating in her field of vision. Fundoscopy revealed the following finding.  What is the CD4+T cell count at which majority of such cases occur?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the pizza pie appearance on fundoscopy, is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. The majority of such cases occur in HIV-infected patients with a CD4+T cell count <50/μL.

CMV retinitis is a necrotic retinal infection that results in a painless irreversible vision loss. Patients may complain of blurred vision, floaters (described by patient as flies or spiders in the field of vision), and scintillations. It is usually bilateral and is characterized by perivascular hemorrhage and exudates in the retina (pizza pie appearance or scrambled eggs and ketchup appearance).

Treatment:

  • Induction - IV ganciclovir (3 weeks)
  • Maintenance - Oral valganciclovir (till CD4 count > 100/μl for 6months)

questions.text: A unemployed HIV-positive patient, resident of a missionary home, presents with 2 weeks of fever, cough and night sweats. He was devastated after getting fired from his job because of his diagnosis and has since been non-compliant to cART. His CD4 count is <10/ μL. CT scan shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection. It is an AIDS-defining opportunistic infection, occurring predominantly at CD4+ T cell counts of <50/μL.

The most common presentation is disseminated disease with fever, weight loss, and night sweats. The diagnosis is made by culture of blood or involved tissue.

CT scan shows peribronchial inflammation of the infected lung giving rise to a tree in a bud appearance (small round structures attached to linear structures) indicated by the arrowhead. In severe cases, there might be bronchiectasis and cavity formation.

Treatment consists of clarithromycin / azithromycin with ethambutol/ rifabutin. Primary prophylaxis with azithromycin is indicated in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <50/μL.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with HIV presents with lab reports showing: Low albumin, massive proteinuria. Renal ultrasound shows large, echogenic kidneys. Blood pressure is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This patient with HIV presents with massive proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia. The most likely cause is HIV-1-associated nephropathy (HIVAN) - a form of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). 

Proteinuria is the hallmark of this disorder. Edema and hypertension are rare. A definitive diagnosis is obtained through renal biopsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common form of heart disease associated with HIV?
questions.solution:
The most common form of heart disease associated with HIV infection is coronary heart disease.

In patients with HIV infection, cardiovascular disease may be a direct consequence of HIV infection, a complication of anti-retroviral therapy or due to classical risk factors like smoking. 

Exposure to HIV protease inhibitors and reverse transcriptase inhibitors have been associated with an increase in total cholesterol and/or risk of MI (Myocardial infarction).

Dilated cardiomyopathy associated with congestive heart failure (CHF) is referred to as HIV-associated cardiomyopathy. This generally occurs as a late complication of HIV infection and, histologically, displays elements of myocarditis.
